node.title: Issue with petsc finding MPI
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I am installing MOOSE on an HPC.
In my environment I have

OpenMPI 4.1
GCC 11.3.0
python 3.11.5
cmake 3.25.2

I am receiving the following error when running ./update_and_rebuild_petch.sh
Unable to find mpi in default locations!

This is odd since, which mpicc returns a valid directory.
I try to manually specify the directory with --with-mpi-dir but that returns the same error. The configure.log file for petsc does not shed anymore light than the output I posted.
I have a valid ./moose_profile with all of the options specified in the HPC tutorial. Using mpich instead of openMPI is not an option for me. At least the cluster I am using does not have any mpich modules.
Any insight would be much appreciated!

I am not sure where we mention a specific MPI wrapper on our HPC instructions: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/hpc_install_moose.html
Given that you go to mention it, can you post the link to the instructions you followed (I am asking because those instructions may be wrong, and I'd like to fix them!)
Looks like you meet all the version requirements. Can you post the results of running the diagnostic script?
cd moose/scripts
./diagnostics.sh
Also, the above diagnostic script does not print out each compiler variable (I really need to add that). So can you also provide what the following returns as well?
echo $CC $CXX $FC $F90 $F77
which $CC $CXX $FC $F90 $F77
which $($CC -show | cut -d\  -f1)
which $($CXX -show | cut -d\  -f1)
which $($FC -show | cut -d\  -f1)
which $($F90 -show | cut -d\  -f1)
which $($F77 -show | cut -d\  -f1)
Thanks!

Thanks for your reply!
I've heard that mpich is more stable than openMPI (however I could be wrong there). I did follow the instructions you posted
Here is the output from the diagnostics.sh

mpicc mpicxx mpif90 mpif90 mpif77

Sorry for the delayed response...
There are a number of issues I see:

You have a path set to what may be our Conda packaged compilers, and your systems OpenMPI
PATH=/ascldap/users/detorre/moose-compilers/mambaforge3/bin:/opt/toss/openmpi/4.1/intel/bin: <trimmed the rest>


The Intel compiler has given us a lot of issues in the past, and that is why you see it listed as "Not supported". But you are of course free to make the attempt! That said, are there any GNU compilers available on your cluster?
Yikes!
$CC --version:

mpicc: error while loading shared libraries: libimf.so: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory

We need to figure out why this is the case. I am hopeful it is due to having both the Conda compiler stack in your PATH as well as the Intel OpenMPI compiler (fixing bullet point 1 may solve this issue).

I think that is about it... The bottom line:
Do not conda activate moose-compilers (if that is what you are doing). We need to get rid of this value in your PATH:
/ascldap/users/detorre/moose-compilers/mambaforge3/bin

And, are there any GNU compilers available? OpenMPI is fine, but we would suggest trying to find one that wraps to GCC instead of Intel.
I implemented your suggestions, and it seems to be working now. Thank you!

Hello
To find those when compiling you set the CC FC and CXX environment variables to the respective mpicc/f90/cxx
Guillaume

Depending on how new your copy of MOOSE is, we have updated our diagnostic script to print out some useful information.
cd moose/scripts
./diagnostics.sh
Should return a bunch OKs if it sees things are good to go. Address any failures, or warnings.
An example run on my machine without 'activating' my environment (aka this would be a failure):

Hi, Guillaume and milljm, sorry, due to our closed computer network environment, I am unable to provide you with incorrect output information and can only use photography.After using ./diagnostics.sh , some errors have occurred

lvkas

looks like the environment variables are properly set for the compiler.
You are missing a python package we need though. Can you install packaging? We usually get it from conda but you might have to do this differently since you are offline
Sure, I can package packaging from the external network and deliver them to the internal network via email.Hope it‘s useful.

uh oh. Python 3.12
I dont think we support that one. @milljm can confirm/
Do you have another one installed by any chance?
nevermind. seems we checked last week and python 3.12 is supported. Or at least 3.12.3 is

Can you get a picture of the top portion of the output? Seeing influential environment paths would be helpful in this instance.
I am leaning toward this being an issue with you supplying a custom compiler, while the build scripts might be picking up another one elsewhere (PATH, LD_LIBRARY_PATH, related issues)

node.title: C++ help

node.bodyText:
hello
comparing two numbers like this in C++ is fine.
However,
(_grad_u[_qp] * _kappa[_qp] * _L[_qp] * _grad_test[_i][_qp]);

looks like the residual of a diffusion-like operator so it seems correct.
however
std::abs((_L[_qp] * _mu[_qp] * (op * op * op - op + 3.0 * op * SumOPj)

does not look like a weak form residual? Unless the 'test' function is implicitly in one of the terms?
Guillaume
the second part is the residual of ACGrGrPoly, which has test function in offdiagonaljacobian and not in residual part. do I have to add the test function in my relation?

If I put test function in the relation, the make happens successfully, but when running input file, it terminates the calculations at time=0. but if I am not putting this condition, my input file runs perfectly fine. Not sure what exactly is happening.
how does it terminate? through non-convergence or through a crash / seg fault?
segmentation fault

you ll want to recompile in debug mode and re-run. This may give you a backtrace that tells you why it seg faults
if not, follow these instructions to obtain that information
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_development/debugging.html

node.title: Setup issue: Test timeout, LibMesh version blank.
node.bodyText:
I am trying to setup MOOSE on a laptop for personal research and study. I have been able to follow the instructions here: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html successfully through cloning MOOSE.
In making the test script by make -j 6 I was running into issues that weren't giving much info, so I switched to make -j 1 as I saw recommended on a number of other posts to avoid running out of memory.
This was the printed error when make failed:
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /home/calebfowler/mooseWorkspace/moose/framework/build/unity_src/variables_Unity.C... x86_64-conda-linux-gnu-c++: fatal error: Killed signal terminated program cc1plus compilation terminated.
But proceeding from there, I eventually hadthe test 'fvkernels/mms/harmonic_interpolation.average/tris' timeout, giving the full output which I'll comment below. I noticed that no version was listed for LibMesh.
fvkernels/mms/harmonic_interpolation.average/tris: Working Directory: /home/calebfowler/mooseWorkspace/moose/test/tests/fvkernels/mms/harmonic_interpolation fvkernels/mms/harmonic_interpolation.average/tris: Running command: python3 -m unittest -v test.TestAverageTriangles fvkernels/mms/harmonic_interpolation.average/tris: Framework Information: fvkernels/mms/harmonic_interpolation.average/tris: MOOSE Version:           git commit bde1548eec on 2023-12-14 fvkernels/mms/harmonic_interpolation.average/tris: LibMesh Version: fvkernels/mms/harmonic_interpolation.average/tris: PETSc Version:           3.20.1 fvkernels/mms/harmonic_interpolation.average/tris: SLEPc Version:           3.20.0 fvkernels/mms/harmonic_interpolation.average/tris: Current Time:            Thu Dec 14 15:06:04 2023 fvkernels/mms/harmonic_interpolation.average/tris: Executable Timestamp:    Thu Dec 14 14:59:51 2023
As such, I have tried rebuilding LibMes, following the instructions here, to no avail. Some of the critical output is listed below https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/build_libmesh.html.
No LSB modules are available. Submodule 'libmesh' (https://github.com/libMesh/libmesh) registered for path 'libmesh' Cloning into '/home/calebfowler/mooseWorkspace/moose/libmesh'...

Running make - j 6
Make: * * * * No targets specified and no makefiles found stop

Hello
You can pass a flag to install without it. It's tied to checkpointing, XDR is the binary format
we are actually supporting a non-binary (ascii) format that  had  the same performance pretty much
Or you need to install libtirpc-devel on your cluster.

node.title: Unit conversion of mesh between the Reactor module and the THM module
node.bodyText: Hello, everyone! I'm using THM's HeatStructureFromFile3D, in which the mesh file is generated by Reactor module. Unfortunately, the unit of mesh from Reactor module is cm but that of THM module is m. I don't know how to do the unit conversion between HeatStructureFromFile3D (mesh file from Reactor module: cm) and FlowChannel1Phase (mesh from THM module: m). Could you please give me some suggestions?

Hello
You can use the coordinate transformation system to perform the conversion between units
The parameters to set are in the mesh block
More details can be found here on the Mesh syntax page
Coordinate Systems
Guillaume
Thanks for your help, it was fixed.

node.title: Restart from Last step
node.bodyText:
Hi, I am using restart in MOOSE
I want to use the previous solid mechanics output, which is .e file.
I have set the disp_x disp_y disp_z, there seems no problem.
But I meet a problem is the stress is zero, what should i do to transfer it?
Thanks for you help!

Hello
You cannot use restart from exodus for solid mechanics. You have to use the checkpoint system for restarting
Guillaume

thanks, i find checkpoint in this link
and a question is there no mention of how to use. Can you give me some examples or other links?

You add a Checkpoint object to your Outputs block to create the checkpoint
and use the restart_file_base parameter in the Problem to use it.
there will be examples in the repository. grep -r restart_file_base will find them

Thanks, I find some examples, and I do as follow:
[Problem]
   restart_file_base = XAPR_heatsource_out_fuelRod0_cp/LATEST
   force_restart = true
[]
the XAPR_heatsource_out_fuleRod0_cp is a subApp, So I use force_restart
But seems doesn't work
WARNING! There are options you set that were not used!
WARNING! could be spelling mistake, etc!
There is one unused database option. It is:
Option left: name:-i value: pulse_project/pulse_heat.i source: command line
I use the command in zsh is  mpiexec -n 40 ./pulse-opt -i pulse_project/pulse_heat.i

Oh, I find the reason
the end time should follow the LATEST

node.title: TensorMechanics error regarding transient vs. Steady solve
node.bodyText:
I'm trying to obtain a steady state solution for a nuclear fuel rod thermal mechanical problem and keep running into the following error:
*** ERROR ***
all_strain: Calling "coupled[Vector][Gradient/Dot]Old[er]" on variable "displacements" when using a "Steady" executioner is not allowed. This value is available only in transient simulations.
I know there's likely a couple errors in my input file since I'm pretty new to MOOSE, but I really can't figure out what is causing this specific error.  I expect there to be some type of mechanical contact between the cladding and fuel surfaces, but haven't been able to figure out how to set that up yet.
For context I' include my set up for the contact and TensorMechanics modules:
[ThermalContact]
[fuel_gap] # Assume gap is filled with helium
type = GapHeatTransfer
variable = temperature
gap_geometry_type = 'CYLINDER'
gap_conductivity = 0.002556 #  W/cm^2-K
primary = fuel_surface
secondary = clad_surface
quadrature = true
emissivity_primary = 0.4
emissivity_secondary = 0.4
[]
[]
[Contact]
[gap]
primary = fuel_surface
secondary = clad_surface
model = frictionless
formulation = mortar
[]
[]
The below is causing problems.
[Modules/TensorMechanics/Master]
[all] # all stresses developed
add_variables = true
strain = FINITE
eigenstrain_names = thermal
generate_output = 'vonmises_stress'
volumetric_locking_connection = true
temperature = temperature
[]
[]
nevermind I found my problem. Needed to use Transient Solve and not Steady Solve since Contact tracks the change in mesh over time

node.title: Function for Initial_condition
node.bodyText:
I have a variable "e" as shown in the below code.  I want to expression (or function) in the place of constant value given to "initial_condition". what should I change?
[Variables]
  [e]
    family = SCALAR
    order = FIRST
    initial_condition = 13.81551056 
    #scaling = 1e-3
  []
[]

[ScalarKernels]

  [de_dt]
    type = ODETimeDerivativeLog
    variable = e
  []

[]

Hello
You use the Scalar----ICs, in the [ICs] block to set an initial condition to ScalarVariables.
Here's a link to the one that can use a function
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/ics/FunctionScalarIC.html
Guillaume
Sure. Is it also allowed to do this through AuxVariables/AuxScalarKernels?

That s ok too
You can execute them on InITIAL it is also the same as an initial condition

Thanks... below one looks OK?
[AuxScalarKernels]
  [H2]
    type = ParsedAuxScalar
    variable = H2
    args = 'Nd'
    function = 'log(Nd)'
    execute_on = 'INITIAL'
  []

There is also another question for me... this variable I want to initialize using an expression is a chemical species, and it has to have time derivative kernel. Is it possible to use an expression for the nonlinear variable instead of using as aux? for example below code, where initial condition is a constant has to be replaced with an expression. How should we do that?
[Variables]
  [H2]
    family = SCALAR
    order = FIRST
    initial_condition = 58
  []
 []

[ScalarKernels]

  [H2]
    type = ODETimeDerivativeLog
    variable = H2
  []
 []

Hello
For more complex intiializations you use the ICs block instead of specify it directly in the Variable
There are many ICs objects you can use.
Auxkernel on initial are also still an option imo
Guillaume

But, variable in AuxKernel, its value will be held constant throughout the simulation and cannot be subjected to a time derivative as this is considered to be a chemical species in this problem statement. Isnt it?

They can be modified by auxkernels on each time step
I dont know actually if the time derivative is not computed. It would be worth checking

node.title: Help with installing MOOSE on HPC
node.bodyText:
I'm trying to install MOOSE on the ALCF Polaris HPC. I have the following environment:
module swap PrgEnv-nvhpc PrgEnv-gnu/8.3.3
module load cray-hdf5-parallel/1.12.2.3
module load cray-fftw/3.3.10.3
module load cray-python/3.9.13.1
module load cmake/3.23.2
export CC=mpicc CXX=mpicxx FC=mpif90 F90=mpif90 F77=mpif77

When running the update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh script, the installation appears to stall indefinitely at the step Configuring SUPERLU_DIST with CMake; this may take several minutes. Here's the config log after terminating the PETSc installation.
configure.log
The installation appears to be stuck while running the following command:

Well, this next trick is going to require a little fineness;

And right after the hang begins, in the other terminal execute this command:
ps -ef | grep youruserid >~/ps_outout.log
Please scrub this log for any personal/identifiable/sensitive information before posting/attaching. Your free to trim everything you think is not related. But the fact will be Cmake will be executing other commands, and we should include those in the log you post.
Edit: Oh, and definitely replace youruserid with your actual User ID on the system :)

Here's the log.
ps_output.log

oh wow, those are very long lines. I might need more of an expert here. If I recall correctly, there is a limit as to the length of the command... Perhaps this is getting in our way. I even see something a bit odd with one of the last bits of these lines:
<trimmed> -L/opt/cray/pe/mpich/8.1.25/ofi/gnu/9.1/lib -lmpi_gnu_91 -I/opt/cray/p

/opt/cray/p doesn't "feel" right. Unless that directory exists? Can you check?
@permcody or @roystgnr I consider very low level Linux dudes. Care to comment on my command line length statement?
Closer inspection it almost looks like the line is repeating somehow (I don't have an idea for a fix yet)
Yea I think the lines are cut off either by a command length or output length limit. Each line length is 131072, which equals 2^17. /opt/cray/p doesn't exist

I don't suppose there is another version of Cmake we can try? Our Conda packages are using 3.28.3 (for reference).
Although, I am doubting its a cmake bug.

node.title: Superconductivity in MOOSE
node.bodyText:
Hi there,
I just wanted to say thank you for all the assistance from the MOOSE team, especially @GiudGiud, in the fruition of my current research.
It has been great to see MOOSE applied to the field of superconductivity.
All the best,
Gillian
Final_report_Final_checks (2).pdf

Thanks for sharing! We are glad to see people pushing MOOSE into new fields!
If you made an app or a repo feel free to share a link for posterity. I may have missed it but I didn't see it in your report.
